channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Who Is Postmaster General Louis DeJoy?
item.description: The official at the center of the controversy over the Postal Service is a major Trump donor with a career in logistics.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins
item.media:credit: Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
item.media:description: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, left, on Capitol Hill in August.

item.title: A Private Security Company Is Detaining Migrant Children at Hotels
item.description: Under emergency coronavirus orders, the Trump administration is using hotels across the country to hold migrant children and families before expelling them.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson
item.media:credit: Matt York/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency has detained migrants in hotels across the southern border, including at a Hampton Inn in Phoenix.

item.title: Turning Grief for a Hidden Past Into a Healing Space
item.description: The University of Virginia in Charlottesville, designed by Thomas Jefferson, was built by enslaved people. The Memorial to Enslaved Laborers acknowledges that long-suppressed history.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.category: Memorial to Enslaved Laborers (University of Virginia)
item.media:credit: Sanjay Suchak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The name of Isabella Gibbons, an enslaved woman who lived and worked at the University of Virginia and became a teacher.

item.title: Rapid Testing is at Parties, Concerts and Hotels. Social Distance Still Required.
item.description: Determined to proceed with parties and events this summer, hosts are adding screenings at the door. But such measures are hardly a guarantee of safety, medical experts warn.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Joe Carrotta for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rite of nasal passage: Amanda Seekamp, who is in charge of guest relations at the Surf Lodge in Montauk, N.Y., gets a rapid test from Dr. Seth Gordon, a private doctor working in Montauk.

item.title: Marvin Creamer, a Mariner Who Sailed Like the Ancients, Dies at 104
item.description: No GPS for him, not even a sextant; the sun and the stars did nicely. He was the first recorded person to sail round the world without navigational instruments.
item.dc:creator: Margalit Fox
item.media:credit: Ralph Harvey, via University Archives and Special Collections, Rowan University Libraries
item.media:description: Marvin Creamer in an undated photo aboard the Globe Star, the 36-foot cutter he used to circumnavigate the globe. He was guided by the wind, waves, the sun by day, and the moon and stars by night.

item.title: U.S. Tries to Bolster Taiwan’s Status, Short of Recognizing Sovereignty
item.description: President Trump prefers a robust relationship with authoritarian China to one with democratic Taiwan. But other American officials aim to strengthen U.S.-Taiwan ties.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Taiwan Presidential Office, via Reuters
item.media:description: Alex M. Azar II, the secretary of health and human services, attended a meeting on Aug. 10 with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan in Taipei.

item.title: Gretchen Whitmer Speaks to The Times
item.description: Ms. Whitmer, the governor of Michigan and a contender on Joe Biden’s short list for V.P., spoke with The Times ahead of her speech on Monday night at the Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Michigan Governors Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Governor Gretchen Whitmer will play a big role in the 2020 election as the Democratic leader of a key battleground state that was key to President Trump’s rise to the presidency in 2016.

item.title: Mail-in voters sue Trump and DeJoy to block cuts at the Postal Service ahead of the election.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Logan Cyrus/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protestors demonstrated in front of the North Carolina home of Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, on Sunday.

item.title: All the Republicans Who Have Decided Not to Support Trump
item.description: Numerous top G.O.P. officials have said publicly or privately that they will not be backing the president’s re-election. Here’s a look at where they stand.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz and Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitt Romney, who has long been critical of President Trump, will not vote for him, according to people familiar with his thinking.

item.title: Schools Reopening in the Covid-19 Pandemic: The State of Play for K-12
item.description: This year is anything but typical, and individual districts have been largely left to chart their own paths.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:credit: Sources: Harvard Global Health Institute, state government
item.media:description: Is your child’s school ready to reopen?

item.title: How Are Student Newspapers Covering Back to School?
item.description: We want to hear how student journalists are approaching this unusual school year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nadia Chin, a yearbook editor at Curtis High School on Staten Island

item.title: Smollett Case: Special Prosecutor Finds ‘Abuses of Discretion’
item.description: An investigation has found that the state’s attorney’s office did not violate the law in its handling of the case against the actor Jussie Smollett, but it cited substantial “operational failures.”
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Ashlee Rezin Garcia/Sun-Times/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Cook County state’s attorney, Kim Foxx. The state’s attorney’s office said that it “categorically rejects” the special prosecutor’s assessment that it made “abuses of discretion” in its communications to the public.

item.title: John Kasich, a ‘Deeply Worried’ Republican, Steps Up for Biden
item.description: John R. Kasich, a lifelong Republican and former rival of President Trump’s will speak at the Democratic convention — and vote for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I happen to think it’s the soul of our country that is being damaged, and that’s what I’m concerned about,” said John R. Kasich, the former Republican governor of Ohio.

item.title: Trump’s Attacks on TikTok and WeChat Could Further Fracture the Internet
item.description: The president’s restrictions on Chinese tech may be part of an eye-for-an-eye logic called reciprocity. The price could be a global patchwork of online fiefs.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Paul Mozur and Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Dae In Chung

item.title: The M.V.P.s of This Year’s Conventions? The Digital and I.T. Teams
item.description: Making sure livestreams don’t lag. Sending out remote video kits. Showing speakers how to avoid microphone mishaps. Digital planners for the conventions have suddenly become all-important.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Almost all of this year’s Democratic National Convention will happen virtually, instead of in Milwaukee as planned, setting high stakes for how technologically smooth the event will be.

item.title: Trump Administration Finalizes Plan to Open Oil Drilling in Alaska's Arctic Refuge
item.description: The decision sets up a fierce legal battle over the fate of a vast, remote area that is home to polar bears, caribou and the promise of oil wealth.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Christopher Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caribou in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. A decision on Monday overturns six decades of protections for the largest remaining stretch of wilderness in the United States.

item.title: What to Know About the Pac-12 in the Fall
item.description: Monday: California is influencing pandemic plans for conferences nationwide. Also: A heat wave hits the state.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Thomas Graning/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Pac-12 won’t play football in the fall, but may try to play in the spring.

item.title: The president’s top donors from 2016 are not giving as much to his re-election.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Karen Yourish
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has collected huge numbers of small donations online, but he lacks robust support from wealthy Republicans.

item.title: Here’s how to watch the Democratic convention.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Democratic National Convention is being held “in” Milwaukee but will be almost entirely virtual.

item.title: Milwaukee loses a mega-event: ‘No Brewers, no Bucks, no convention.’
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bars in Milwaukee, America’s most beer-loving city, had anticipated doing brisk business at an in-person convention.

item.title: A Big Ol’ Virtual Experiment
item.description: Here’s what we’re watching as the Democrats begin their week of nightly Zoom addresses.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Is Herd Immunity Ahead of Schedule?
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Indranil Mukherjee/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In Mumbai, a randomized household survey found that about 57 percent of people who live in the poorest areas and share toilets have antibodies, compared with just 11 percent elsewhere in the city.

item.title: Covid-19 Live Updates
item.description: Louis DeJoy, the U.S. postmaster general, agreed to testify before the House Oversight Committee on Aug. 24. A South Korean pastor whose church is at the center of a new outbreak has tested positive.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The ‘Rage Moms’ Democrats Are Counting On
item.description: As millions of American families face an uncertain start to the school year, the anger of women who find themselves expected to be teacher, caregiver, employee and parent is fueling a political uprising.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Wall of Moms that emerged from the Portland protests is one of the latest examples of parents engaging in activism to strengthen the social safety net.

item.title: Covid-19: What if ‘Herd Immunity’ Is Closer Than Scientists Thought?
item.description: In what may be the world’s most important math puzzle, researchers are trying to figure out how many people in a community must be immune before the coronavirus fades.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Borough Park neighborhood of Brooklyn was hit hard by the coronavirus, reaching thousands of cases and hundreds of deaths by April.

item.title: The Recession Is About to Slam Cities. Not Just the Blue-State Ones.
item.description: Those with budgets that rely heavily on tourism, sales taxes or direct state assistance will face particular distress.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger and Quoctrung Bui
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rochester, N.Y., which relies heavily on state aid, already has deferred millions of dollars of nonessential expenses.

item.title: A College’s ‘Free Speech Areas’ Face Supreme Court Review
item.description: The justices will consider whether a student’s First Amendment lawsuit may proceed after a college in Georgia abandoned its restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments this fall on whether Chike Uzuegbunam can sue college officials for violating his First Amendment rights.

item.title: Trump as a Candidate: Racism, Conspiracies and a War on the USPS
item.description: President Trump long ago redefined what constitutes normal in the White House, but with 77 days left in the campaign he is pushing all the boundaries at once.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with the first lady, Melania Trump, and their son, Barron. Mr. Trump has jumped from one norm-busting statement or action to the next during his presidency.

item.title: The Conventions Are Starting. Cue the Virtual Excitement.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about the unconventional conventions.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: What Historical Moment Is Leon Neyfakh Learning From Now?
item.description: The creators of “Slow Burn” have a new season of their podcast “Fiasco,” which looks at the yearslong fight over school desegregation in Boston.
item.dc:creator: Jonah Engel Bromwich
item.media:credit: Thomas McCarty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Neyfakh, 35, has become known for podcasts that excavate the recent past.

item.title: The Political Conventions Are Starting. Here’s What to Expect.
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has changed nearly every facet of life in 2020, and the political conventions are no exception. Our reporters catch you up on what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr, Jeff Bernier, Aaron Byrd and Christina Kelso
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Bernie Lost Again, but This Time He’ll Deliver a Victory Speech at DNC
item.description: Progressive candidates are winning. The pandemic increased support for “Medicare for all.” What does Mr. Sanders make of it? “He may feel a little bit like Moses.”
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders is no longer the defiant insurgent he was in 2016.

item.title: The DNC Night 1: Explained
item.description: Michelle Obama will appear, and Democrats will see whether there’s an anti-Trump consensus or a mishmash of messaging, with speakers ranging ideologically from Bernie Sanders to John Kasich.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign for the Democratic National Convention at the Miller High Life Theater in Milwaukee. The city was supposed to host the convention, but because of the coronavirus crisis, almost all of it will be held virtually.

item.title: DNC Speakers, Start Time, Schedule, Channel, Live Stream and More
item.description: Michelle Obama and Bernie Sanders will headline the first night of the convention on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Democratic National Convention, initially planned for Milwaukee, will now be mostly virtual and will air from 9 p.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern this week, Monday through Thursday.

item.title: Texas Man Surrenders to Police, Ending 16-Hour Standoff
item.description: Three police officers were injured in a shooting that began the standoff, the authorities in Cedar Park, Texas, said.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah and Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Andy Way/KKAN-TV, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency vehicles were massed on a street in Cedar Park, Texas, where three police officers were shot and a man was barricaded in a home on Sunday.

item.title: Melinda Gates On Covid-19: It’s Time to Demand More of All Our Leaders
item.description: “We have to vote for the right people. And then we have to hold our leaders accountable,” the philanthropist said.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Donner

item.title: Can Los Angeles Schools Test 700,000 Students and 75,000 Employees? That’s the Plan
item.description: Classes will start remotely. But the nation’s second-largest school district has perhaps the most ambitious plan to test students and employees for the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Rodin Eckenroth/Getty Images
item.media:description: Students waiting to pick up school resources at Hollywood High School in Hollywood, Calif., on Thursday.

item.title: Scientists See Signs of Lasting Immunity to Covid-19, Even After Mild Infections
item.description: New research indicates that human immune system cells are storing information about the coronavirus so they can fight it off again.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Medical workers taking a blood test for antibodies in Miami Lakes, Fla., in July.

item.title: Fire Tornadoes Reported in Northern California Wildfire
item.description: The National Weather Service issued an unusual warning on Saturday about the possibility of “a fire-induced tornado.”
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.media:credit: Katelynn Hewlett, via Reuters
item.media:description: A funnel in the Loyalton Fire in California on Saturday. Fire tornadoes spawn in a combination of extreme heat from fire, turbulent winds and uneven terrain, a meteorologist said.

item.title: It’s Convention Time: 2-Minute Speeches, No Pomp, a Forlorn Milwaukee
item.description: The Democratic convention starts Monday. But none of the leading participants will be in Milwaukee, the host city. Hotels there were closed and the bars of America’s most beer-loving city were eerily barren.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Democratic National Convention is advertised at the Miller High Life Theater in Milwaukee on Sunday.
